post_text: We had a prospective patient reach out to us today who is hearing impaired. Requesting a ASL interpreter, saying that if we don‚Äôt have one on staff, we are required to provide one at our expense per ADA laws. The cost will be about $40 more than the whole session would reimburse. Does anyone have any experience with this?

comments.text:
ADA Title III (for private providers): Physical therapy offices are "places of public accommodation." They must ensure effective communication by furnishing auxiliary aids and services, including qualified sign language interpreters, unless it causes an undue burden (significant difficulty or expense, considering the provider's resources)

If you are a very small clinic you could make the argument that it would cause and undue burden and offer to help find a clinic that can accommodate

If the clinic doesn‚Äôt receive any federal funding, I don‚Äôt think you ‚Äúhave to.‚Äù So if you accept Medicaid or Medicare, I think you do. If you were say private pay or private insurance only I don‚Äôt think you have to. Not a lawyer but that is my understanding‚Ä¶

post_text: Looking for advice: my business partner and I are opening our first clinic and looking to contract with some insurances. We applied for Aetna and were sent a ‚Äúprovider agreement‚Äù it was very vague, not identifying CPT codes, no fee schedule etc. We called to see if this was our final contract and were told ‚Äúno this is just the first step and after we credential you then you get your final contract and can negotiate.‚Äù We got an email saying we‚Äôre part of the network and provided an effective date but no further contract details. We called today and were told that the ‚Äúprovider agreement‚Äù is the final contract and we should have requested the fee schedule and asked to negotiate before signing, that the other info provided was incorrect. We feel silly because this is our first go with all of this and we were provided incorrect info. Does anyone know if we can void the contract before the effective date and start again or are we stuck with just having agreed to whatever Aetna wants to pay us? (we requested they send a fee schedule but haven‚Äôt gotten it yet) Any advice is appreciated!

comments.text:
No need to feel silly and try not to beat yourselves up they intentionally do this to trip people up. I call it weaponized incompetence. When you‚Äôre just starting you‚Äôre bound to make mistakes. 

You may want to consider asking your state association if they have any advice they usually have pretty good relationships with ppl at the insurance carriers. 

ASH tried pulling something similar with me. They told me everything was square sent over the contract however they conveniently only sent over the pages that I had to sign and left out all of the important details of the contract. Luckily I caught it and forced them to send over everything. 

Honestly you can probably just chalk this one up as a learning experience. Never trust anything an insurance carrier tells you and get everything in writing with reference numbers and names.
if the agreement doesn‚Äôt work for you and you can‚Äôt renegotiate, would simply not taking a referral from them works? Assuming you are working on other contracts as well.

full_thread_text:

ASH tried pulling something similar with me. They told me everything was square sent over the contract however they conveniently only sent over the pages that I had to sign and left out all of the important details of the contract. Luckily I caught it and forced them to send over everything.

post_text:
I currently was/am a travel PT. I am off contract right now. However, due to personal reasons I am not leaving a specific area right now until at least June 2026. This is not my tax home area. I am struggling to find a travel contract in this area I am in and may have to settle for PRN in a SNF as there are literally no full time jobs unless you want to work in an OP mill.

 I specialize in pelvic health and I am considering offering some virtual sessions with it leading to possible mobile depending how well it goes in the meantime. I know wherever my partner and I go next (based on his job) it will be a larger city and I will be able to open my own brick and mortar eventually.

Due to only being in this area for about 8 more months I do not want to go through the hassle of doing all this LLC paperwork and then we move to a different city or to a completely different state. If I was to do virtual or mobile can I do it as a sole prop with liability insurance through CM&F? Then file an LLC wherever we go next?

comments.text:
The structure of the business is usually state specific, so you'll have to look up the laws and see if they will accept a healthcare provider filing as a sole proprietor.

You could also look at virtual positions with hinge health or other online platforms.

post_text: I have an employee who is planning to start her own clinic and take some of our patients with her. I was trying to be chill about it as it is a neuro caseload and our bread and butter is hand therapy. I have, though, put a ton of money and effort into building that caseload. Over the last couple of weeks, she has given her new card to people and has even said to me that she‚Äôs getting credentialed with such and such insurance so she can take patient x. It has felt very triggering and stressful so I have decided to let her go now rather than letting her work a few more weeks for me. She is acting like I am being very unreasonable. Am I being unreasonable?

comments.text: That is not ok of that therapist. Whenever I‚Äôm leaving a position, I‚Äôll only tell them where I‚Äôm going if they ask and I stay vague without offering any information. If they persist, I‚Äôll take their number and if they reach out, they have a right to stay with someone they‚Äôre comfortable with. Soliciting for a direct competitor at your workplace is really not ok

While a non compete is hard to enforce, you can‚Äôt prevent people from working. Poaching clients is different. That is a non solicitation agreement. 

Here are some options:

Potential legal claims without a non-compete Even if a non-compete agreement is invalid, an employer can pursue legal action against a former employee for "poaching" clients under other legal principles. 

1. Breach of fiduciary duty or duty of loyalty During employment: An employee owes a duty of loyalty to their employer. If an employee tries to steal clients while they are still on the company payroll, they can be sued for a breach of this duty.

"Corporate opportunity" doctrine: Some courts may view soliciting clients for a competing business during employment as taking an opportunity that rightfully belonged to the employer. 

2. Misappropriation of trade secrets 
Confidential information: If an employee uses confidential or proprietary information, such as a client list, pricing strategy, or internal data, to solicit clients, they can be sued for trade secret misappropriation.

Misappropriation laws: The Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA), adopted by most U.S. states, protects companies from employees using trade secrets for their own benefit. 

3. Tortious interference
Interfering with a contract: An employer can file a claim for tortious interference if a former employee intentionally and improperly disrupts the company's contractual relationships with its clients, causing financial damage.

Interfering with a business relationship: 
This claim is similar to tortious interference with a contract but applies when no formal contract exists. It involves improperly interfering with the company's prospective business relationships.

post_text:
Do you provide company computer or do you allow therapists to use their computers?
Feedback have been that they like using their personal computer better. If that‚Äôs the case what do we need to install to be HIPAA compliance

comments.text: Depending on the specific operations I‚Äôd be careful letting them use their own because you don‚Äôt know what security settings they may have or malware etc. plus it‚Äôd be easier for them to steal info if the relationship goes south.

I realized this is a NBCOT question. 

It‚Äôs a huge ethical dilemma to use a personal device for EMR. It puts the company more at risk for HIPAA violation and if audited the entire device can be searched not just the EMR which means the therapist could get in trouble for other things they look at or participate in their personal life.

post_text:
Are you aware that at any time, a politically appointed (not elected) state board can strip you of your license ‚Äî your career, your reputation, your livelihood ‚Äî over a treatment you‚Äôve never received a single complaint about?

They don‚Äôt even need to cite a valid regulation. In fact, they don‚Äôt have to follow any existing regulation at all. They can invent one on the spot, and weaponize it against you ‚Äî retroactively ‚Äî to destroy everything you‚Äôve built. And if you think poor reimbursement is the biggest threat to our profession, just wait until you experience being professionally erased without cause or accountability.

This is what our field has become.

And when it happens to you? Don‚Äôt expect help from:
 ‚Ä¢ The APTA
 ‚Ä¢ The FSBPT
 ‚Ä¢ The Governor, AG, or your legislators
 ‚Ä¢ Any civil rights or whistleblower organization

They‚Äôll all say how terrible your situation is ‚Äî but none of them will lift a finger. The system protects itself. The courts will side with other government agencies while your due process, constitutional rights, and professional dignity are obliterated.

If this can happen to one of us, it can happen to any of us.

#ProtectPTs
#DueProcessMatters
#UnaccountableBoards
#RestoreJusticeInHealthcare

comments.text:
After an unblemished 20-year career with no prior complaints, my professional life was dismantled by a coordinated campaign of retaliation, regulatory overreach, and political targeting.

It began with a former employee who violated her non-compete agreement, admitted to taking patients, and settled out of court. That same individual, aligned with a direct competitor, threatened to ‚Äúget even.‚Äù Shortly after, multiple complaints were filed‚Äînot for any treatment rendered, but for recommending a valid, evidence-based clinical option that was never even performed.

The very day my wife and I took possession of our new facility to expand our business, I was summarily suspended.

What followed was an unprecedented 15+ hour hearing that resembled a kangaroo court more than a fair administrative process:
 ‚Ä¢ All expert witnesses were excluded.
 ‚Ä¢ Over 300 letters of support from patients and providers were ignored.
 ‚Ä¢ The sitting Board president admitted he was unfamiliar with the applicable rules and regulations.
 ‚Ä¢ The lead investigator testified she hadn‚Äôt reviewed the case file or any of the submitted evidence.

Despite this, I was indefinitely suspended‚Äîinitially for ‚Äúno less than two years,‚Äù now approaching four‚Äîbased solely on a recommendation, not a treatment, involving a patient who continued under my care for nearly a decade and never filed a complaint.

The charge? A non-existent regulation fabricated on the spot‚Äîretroactively applied to conduct from 2015‚Äîin blatant violation of the Administrative Process Act and the authority of the Virginia General Assembly. And these phantom rules? Enforced exclusively against me.

But it gets worse.

The Department of Health Professions (DHP), Board of Physical Therapy (BOPT), and Board of Nursing (BON) were complicit in altering medical records‚Äîfalsely relabeling physical therapy patients as massage therapy clients. The BON, which has no jurisdiction over PT practice, then judged my physical therapy treatment under massage therapy standards. Although even they didn‚Äôt find the patient as credible as the BOPT claimed, they issued a formal reprimand‚Äîplacing a blemish on my massage license for a patient who was never a massage client.

Now, nearly four years later, the Board is attempting to revoke my license permanently.

Meanwhile, the disciplinary double standard is staggering:
 ‚Ä¢ A female PT who had sexual relations with multiple patients received probation.
 ‚Ä¢ Another female PT who treated patients under the influence and received a DUI served a one-year suspension.
 ‚Ä¢ A Board ‚Äúwitness‚Äù who disregarded physician orders and patient consent continues to practice without sanction.
 ‚Ä¢ A male therapist who slept with a 19-year-old patient and practiced without a license was suspended for under a year‚Äîwith no ongoing restrictions.
 ‚Ä¢ Another male therapist arrested twice for sexual assault was suspended for three months the first time, one year the second‚Äîand is now back in practice, unrestricted.

Yet I remain indefinitely suspended‚Äînearly four years and counting‚Äîfor recommending a clinically valid, expert-supported treatment option that has never drawn a single patient complaint.

This is not regulation. This is retribution.
This is not oversight. This is targeted persecution.
And unless it is exposed, it will continue to happen to others.
Need more context.

post_text:
Hi! I‚Äôm looking for insurance guidance. What types of insurance and how much coverage? I need someone with more experience! 

I started a LLC and will be doing mobile outpatient visits, personal training/wellness, and eventually will have Pilates/a physical location.

comments.text:
Everyone is different and needs are different; but we use CM&F group; was significantly cheaper and easier to work with than HPSO (which is usually the APTA referral partner)  

It does not matter what type of services you are offering wellness/PT or personal training they aren't going after the service they would be going after you and the business so you are protecting that.  
You will need liability insurance; if you are contracting with insurance providers they usually require a 1M/3M policy minimum, some are higher.   
General liability insurance if you have a physical space, and if you do not own it the lease agreement usually spells out what is/is not covered and how much insurance they require you to carry. 
Cybersecurity insurance for malware or ransomware attacks- most dont get this, but I see this becoming a requirement by all federal payers soon. 

If you are doing mobile visits you will want to make sure your umbrella policy covers incidental damage to someones home etc and or a rider to cover you for accident damage such as busting up a wall or breaking a vase etc... 

You have an LLC set up, perfect, do make sure you have a business bank account; and set up a retirement account for your business ASAP;  keep your business finances separate from your personal life. separation of church and state... if you're solo and have no employees a soloK is the way to go; whether Roth or traditional qualified-- depends on your earnings, expected earnings tax brackets etc. .. discuss with your CPA or financial advisor. 

Happy to answer any other question you have. 
Im a DPT that is also a licensed financial advisor

post_text: Happy Friday!  I have a superbill question. I‚Äôm a solo practitioner in a cashed based clinic. I have a type 2 NPI listed on my super bills and had a client reach out today asking I correct 2 super bills to include my individual NPI per her insurance request.  I‚Äôve never used my individual NPI in 4 years so wondering if this is a mistake from her insurance or if I should have included it this whole time?

comments.text: Hi! So I literally had this come up yesterday except insurance was trying to have the patient use my NPI type 1 to see me in network prior to seeing me. I called and explained that I would be billing under NPI type 2. They understood (which I was surprised about) and would call them and let them know they could only use me as OON. So maybe if they want both NPIs, list one as ‚Äúbilling NPI‚Äù.
Superbill or CMS 1500 should include NPI 2 as billing NPI and individual NPI as rendering provider

So maybe if they want both NPIs, list one as ‚Äúbilling NPI‚Äù.

post_text:
Hey friends! I'm a PT at a private cash-based neuro clinic. I do not own the clinic. 

We have had 2 separate clients in the last two weeks ask if it would be possible for one of the therapists to come to their home and help them with swimming in their personal pools. 

While I do think this could be hugely beneficial, of course there could be liability in conflicts of interest. Both clients have specifically reported that they would still come to our clinic for physical therapy outside of the pool but would want pool therapy a couple times to make themselves and/or their caregivers or family members more comfortable and assisting them in and out of the pool. 

Thoughts? My first concern is of course just liability reasons, but I would love to find a way to help these particular clients with this in a legal and ethical way. 

Any assistance or advice appreciated!

comments.text:
*Maintain or obtain personal liability insurance that will cover you on client property. *Obtain proper certification for aqua therapy and/or swim and water safety training. (So many online options)
*Create an LLC for your ‚Äúcompany‚Äù . 
*Inform your employer if you choose that you will be offering these services to them as a separate entity to the neuro PT.
*You can probably do all of the above steps in a day.

Not sure what state you live in, but in NH, if outpatient services are delivered in the home‚Ä¶a homecare license is required. It requires a lengthy application process and then annual renewal with an audit/survey process. I would look into any similar requirements with DHHS in your state. We have a clinic as well, so we have to assign the site of service as home or clinic for each visit. Our EMR lets us assign the site of service when we schedule the patient.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey friends! I'm a PT at a private cash-based neuro clinic. I do not own the clinic. 

We have had 2 separate clients in the last two weeks ask if it would be possible for one of the therapists to come to their home and help them with swimming in their personal pools. 

While I do think this could be hugely beneficial, of course there could be liability in conflicts of interest. Both clients have specifically reported that they would still come to our clinic for physical therapy outside of the pool but would want pool therapy a couple times to make themselves and/or their caregivers or family members more comfortable and assisting them in and out of the pool. 

Thoughts? My first concern is of course just liability reasons, but I would love to find a way to help these particular clients with this in a legal and ethical way. 

Any assistance or advice appreciated!

COMMENT 1: *Maintain or obtain personal liability insurance that will cover you on client property. *Obtain proper certification for aqua therapy and/or swim and water safety training. (So many online options)
*Create an LLC for your ‚Äúcompany‚Äù . 
*Inform your employer if you choose that you will be offering these services to them as a separate entity to the neuro PT.
*You can probably do all of the above steps in a day.

COMMENT 2: Not sure what state you live in, but in NH, if outpatient services are delivered in the home‚Ä¶a homecare license is required. It requires a lengthy application process and then annual renewal with an audit/survey process. I would look into any similar requirements with DHHS in your state. We have a clinic as well, so we have to assign the site of service as home or clinic for each visit. Our EMR lets us assign the site of service when we schedule the patient.

post_text:
Hello felllow Uncaged!  This post is a follow-up to a post that I made last week about offering paid wellness visits that are NOT considered PT.  I met with my lawyer today, and she told me the following facts that I thought you all might find useful:

1) While it is possible (of course) to charge for this service, whether it is considered "legally physical therapy" or not is up to the law where the patient is present when receiving the service.  For example, If the patient is in Ontario when you performed the service (in person or over phone/video) you would be subject to laws in Ontario.  It is nearly impossible to know how each jurisdiction would behave in the event of a law violation or complaint EVERYWHERE in the world.  

2)  The typical course of action of a governing board such as a state PT board to a practic act violation would be a cease and desist.  If you are sent a cease and desist, you can try to present evidence that you are NOT, in fact, violating the practice act to see if you can convince them to let you continue, or you could simply cease and desist and let it go.  They would only have you cease and desist in THEIR jurisdiction.  For example if the California state board felt that you were performing PT without a license there, they would send you a letter demanding you cease and desist what you are doing IN California.  The chances of legal repercussions or losing your license is low.

3)  You need to advertise what you are doing clearly and specify how it is NOT physical therapy.  The best method to do this is to define Physical therapy as precisely as possible (I.e. performed by a licensed physical therapist, consists of an evaluation, PT diagnoses, customized goals and treatment), and then point out that your wellness program is NOT that (i.e. can be performed by a person who is NOT a licensed physical therapist, does NOT include an evaluation, PT diagnosis, or customized goals and treatment).

4) My lawyer suggested having a contract for the client to sign where they agree to terms, including that they have been informed that this is not PT and will not include anything that would be considered PT or would take the place of medical treatment.  I'm sure that's not all the contract will cover, but she is writing up something formal for me.

5)  Medical liability insurance may not cover a consultation like service.  You need to check with your liability insurance company about whether they would cover it, and if not you need to get general business liability insurance.

6)  Keep records of visits, but those records should not look like a medical record or a Pt evaluative or treatment note in any way.

7)  Treatment or advice cannot be custom unless you are referring to things other providers have already diagnosed them with/advised them of.  Example:  if a neurologist has diagnosed someone with Parkinson's, you can provide them with a general handout from the Parkinson's foundation and go over it with them.  Example 2:  If a doctor had ordered PT for this person recently, but the patient refused to go due to the time commitment as the clinic is far away, you could encourage them to go to PT and help them find a clinic that is nearer to them.

8.  USE YOUR PT KNOWLEDGE to know what is considered NOT PT!  You are literally the expert witness they might call to see if someone who is claiming not to practice PT is practicing PT!  You know the definition because you are the expert.  So don't do anything that is considered PT!

comments.text: I was just dealing with this very issue for a prospective telehealth client - thank you!
Re:#5, are ‚Äúfree consults‚Äù in a typical PT sense covered by our traditional liability?????

post_text:
TEXAS practitioners***

I am desperate for some clarity.

I am a PLLC only providing OT services at this time. I am wanting to add PT and ST services so this requires me to amend my PLLC to LLC per entity rules.

I had a meeting with a buisness lawyer today to assist with amending my PLLC to LLC correctly. He said that per CPOM rules for TX this will be out of compliance with healthcare regulations in our state of Tx. I am assuming that most LLCs provide multiple discipline services, so how are all these practices compliant? Do therapy practice apply to CPOM rules?

comments.text: If you are NOT a licensed home health agency in Texas (which cost thousands of $$ & a lot of time to become); then you are credentialing everything under you and only you. You are a third party payment if you are not & have to be set up as TPR which is what he is saying but under 3rd party, you will need to see if you can operate w/ other disciplines (all of this will open doors of being audited by the srate, & you will get audited). It is how you are set up. I would take a home health agency set up course to help understand.

I believe that If you are going to provide professional services of any sort it has to be under a PLLC an LLC wouldn‚Äôt suffice for professional services. 

Why would you want to convert it to an LLC?

post_text: I am looking to start my own cash based business out of a local gym. I have professional liability insurance through HPSO and am getting my LLC setup. Do I also need business insurance? And is malpractice insurance the same as the liability insurance or do I need that as well? I‚Äôm in PA. Thank you!

comments.text:
Malpractice is ‚ÄúProfessional Liability‚Äù insurance and it‚Äôs different from a general liability policy. General liability would cover people getting hurt on property. Commercial peoperty insurance covers you for theft, fire, flood, etc. business owners insurance (BOP) combines general liability, property and income insurance. Umbrella is an added layer that can cover some additional things.

You should have some sort of liability insurance in addition to your malpractice insurance. Most commercial landlords will require some sort of liability and property insurance. I would recommend getting an umbrella policy added on as well.

Commercial peoperty insurance covers you for theft, fire, flood, etc. business owners insurance (BOP) combines general liability, property and income insurance. Umbrella is an added layer that can cover some additional things.

There is a chiropractor in town that advertises on his webpage that they offer ‚Äúphysiotherapy‚Äù in the office.  Under the description of ‚Äúphysiotherapy‚Äù, it lists out only modalities (ESTIM, cryotherapy, moist heat, etc).  Under the chiropractic description they state they offer a blueprint of exercises designed to help with their manipulations‚Äù   They do not have a PT on staff.  
Is this legal for them to use the term ‚Äúphysiotherapy‚Äù without a PT?   If not, what is the best way to address this?   I‚Äôd like to use them as a referral source as they just moved in to the building next to me, so I do not want to ruffle feathers, but I also don‚Äôt like how they are downplaying the term physiotherapy to just modalities.   (I‚Äôm in Kentucky if it makes any difference.)

comments.text:
Definitely a report to the state board. 
This is a big pet peeve of mine, as they wouldn‚Äôt wait a single second to report a PT for advertising ‚Äúadjustments‚Äù. 
I learned after having a similar conversation with a local chiro that they can take an elective ‚Äúboard exam‚Äù on ‚Äúphysiotherapy‚Äù which is essentially just modalities. But they‚Äôre pretty quick to change their tune once they find out they are illegally misrepresenting their business. 
Needs to stay in his lane.
They are allowed. As Chiro has a certificate in physiotherapy and rehab so they can use it. So long as they are not advertising ‚ÄúPhysial Therapy‚Äù formally. Just word games.

post_text: Does a 1099 still have to have their NPI registered to my business? I‚Äôm assuming yes

comments.text: Yes for Medicare.

Think of an NPI as a ss#.  You can work for numerous companies and report taxes within a timeframe.

Similarly, an NPI can be associated with multiple corporations and self employment simultaneously.

If you are curious about skirting contractual obligations it comes down to a tax id.  Be prepared with clear distinctions and paper trail, starting with client signatures on some kind of form explaining the out of network agreement for specific hours, days, locations, niche services etc.

full_thread_text:
POST: Does a 1099 still have to have their NPI registered to my business? I‚Äôm assuming yes

COMMENT 1: Yes for Medicare.

COMMENT 2: Think of an NPI as a ss#.  You can work for numerous companies and report taxes within a timeframe.

Similarly, an NPI can be associated with multiple corporations and self employment simultaneously.

If you are curious about skirting contractual obligations it comes down to a tax id.  Be prepared with clear distinctions and paper trail, starting with client signatures on some kind of form explaining the out of network agreement for specific hours, days, locations, niche services etc.

post_text: Hey guys! Quick question. Is emailing my previous patients from my old corporate job about my new cash paying PT business unethical or a hippa violation? I have about 8 to 10 patients that I happen to have their email addresses from some internal reviews they posted within the company. They posted about me and I wasn‚Äôt sure how to proceed because I had a good relationship with them and I would like to let them know where I am now, but I also don‚Äôt want to violate anything by sending them an email. Please advise üòä

comments.text: I would not. It could be construed as a HIPAA violation as to how you got their personal information outside of work

It could be viewed as ‚Äúunethical‚Äù from a business perspective and your former employer could take legal action for ‚Äúpoaching‚Äù and soliciting their patients  even if you directly were treating them  Technically and legally it is their patients - not yours. This does not include if you also signed any NDA ,  Non-compete is the least of your worries and does not really apply here depending on your state laws. 

It does violate certain HIPAA practice standards since you should not even have their email addresses those should have been discarded upon leaving your former employer - much less attempt to contact them.

There is ‚Äúfreedom of choice‚Äù so if the patients do not want to continue with their current provider and decide to seek you out on their own without being influenced from outside sources, then there is nothing your employer can do and your golden.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey guys! Quick question. Is emailing my previous patients from my old corporate job about my new cash paying PT business unethical or a hippa violation? I have about 8 to 10 patients that I happen to have their email addresses from some internal reviews they posted within the company. They posted about me and I wasn‚Äôt sure how to proceed because I had a good relationship with them and I would like to let them know where I am now, but I also don‚Äôt want to violate anything by sending them an email. Please advise üòä

COMMENT 1: I would not. It could be construed as a HIPAA violation as to how you got their personal information outside of work

COMMENT 2: It could be viewed as ‚Äúunethical‚Äù from a business perspective and your former employer could take legal action for ‚Äúpoaching‚Äù and soliciting their patients  even if you directly were treating them  Technically and legally it is their patients - not yours. This does not include if you also signed any NDA ,  Non-compete is the least of your worries and does not really apply here depending on your state laws. 

It does violate certain HIPAA practice standards since you should not even have their email addresses those should have been discarded upon leaving your former employer - much less attempt to contact them.

There is ‚Äúfreedom of choice‚Äù so if the patients do not want to continue with their current provider and decide to seek you out on their own without being influenced from outside sources, then there is nothing your employer can do and your golden.

post_text: I work for a large hospital system, and am starting my own cash based mobile practice. comments.text: I was told when I started to create a type 2 NPI for the business (I have an LLC) if you plan on providing super bills for your patients to seek reimbursement. post_text:
Wondering if anyone has ever continuously used ChatGPT to treat a patient? I have a PI patient whose attorney is refusing to seek translator services because ‚Äútechnology is enough.‚Äù
This patient had a consult with an ortho that refers to me and he said it was a disaster with communication because nothing was translating over correctly (Korean to English and vice versa). He actually told the attorney he cannot see this patient unless an actual interpreter is present and has not heard back.
Wondering if I should do the same or if anyone has had success utilizing it?

comments.text:
This is a title VI issue. 

You are actually required by law to provide a qualified translator for this patient. Google translate it chat GPT or even a family member of the patient would not meet the requirement. In the event a translator is not provided, the patient could sue for discrimination. In the event of a poor outcome or injury, the patient could sue claiming negligence... which makes sense really. You can't treat without an eval and you can't really evaluate properly f you can't communicate.

The big sticker here is who pays for the translator. I've had to eat the cost when the Medicare is the payer since they won't reimburse for it.

You can Google and see some legal precedent. Off the top of my mind I can recall a case where an OBGYN was sued for discrimination for not providing an interpreter and another where an ER doctor was sued because a family member of the patient mistranslated something which led to delayed treatment and poor outcome.

Comprehend Health is an AI medical scribe that works with over 57 languages. It can listen to the conversation and input the transcript from the conversation into English. There are quite a few PTs in AZ using it now with their Spanish speaking clients and having good success. Plus it autofills in your EMR based on the transcript so you can truly focus on just treating. 

Like someone said above though, as a medical provider, I believe you have to offer interpreter services.

This patient had a consult with an ortho that refers to me and he said it was a disaster with communication because nothing was translating over correctly (Korean to English and vice versa). Wondering if I should do the same or if anyone has had success utilizing it?

You can Google and see some legal precedent. Off the top of my mind I can recall a case where an OBGYN was sued for discrimination for not providing an interpreter and another where an ER doctor was sued because a family member of the patient mistranslated something which led to delayed treatment and poor outcome.

COMMENT 2: Comprehend Health is an AI medical scribe that works with over 57 languages. It can listen to the conversation and input the transcript from the conversation into English. There are quite a few PTs in AZ using it now with their Spanish speaking clients and having good success. Plus it autofills in your EMR based on the transcript so you can truly focus on just treating. 

Like someone said above though, as a medical provider, I believe you have to offer interpreter services.

post_text:
Hi everyone, I‚Äôm planning on opening my mobile pelvic health business in mid June. I currently have a noncompete agreement that my lawyer has advised me not to worry too much about because of the new FTC ruling.

My main question regards a patient of mine who I have treated on and off for the better part of 3 years. The next closest pelvic health clinician is located about 30 min away, and she has spoken to me multiple times about not wanting to see anyone else due to the chronic and very personal nature of her issues. 

I will preface this by saying that I don‚Äôt want to poach patients, at all. I‚Äôm not planning on telling any of my patients where I‚Äôm going because I don‚Äôt want to steal business from my current employer. But I‚Äôm not sure what to say to this specific patient because I know she will want to follow me (and I‚Äôd be lying if I said I didn‚Äôt want her to!). Does anyone have any suggestions on how to handle this?? More than anything I‚Äôm afraid of it someone getting back to my administrators that I told a patient where I was going, knowing she would leave with me. I‚Äôm already nervous about starting my own business with an active noncompete agreement, and I don‚Äôt want to add fuel to the fire.

Thanks everyone!

comments.text: I have always told my patients if they ever need to contact me, down the road and I am no longer at that clinic or they are looking for a specialty PT to check the APTA website for find a PT. Did that long before starting my own practice. Surprising how many patients remembered and looked me up years after treating them.

The bigger issue than the non compete is a non solicit agreement that is likely in your contract. 

My suggestion would be this, go to the owner of the company you currently work for and let them decide. It should be their decision to let you take a patient.

post_text:
Question about adding providers:

We are a physical therapy cash pay clinic. To help offset rent and add to our services we are looking to add other providers like massage therapists, dieticians, mental performance coaches etc. 

Does anyone know if we need to do anything legally from a business point of view? We are a single member LLC. 

Thanks!

comments.text: There may be some rules in your state business laws that you need to investigate first. Each state is so different. Some states do have regulations related to offering multiple professional services (for which the state provides professional licenses) under a particular business structure. Once that is clarified you can then look at other factors that come into play. As mentioned above practice acts related to referrals etc. Then once you have reviewed all of those rules then you need to look at Professional Liability coverage as well as general liability coverage issues. You should get a few quotes: CMF, HSPO, Proliability. Proliability has generally provided the most cost-effective options but not always. Then the next question becomes the financial aspects of will this actually be profitable. What does this really look like?
Liability insurance umbrella policy for your staff. CM&F is the cheapest I have found

post_text:
Topic: NPI 1/NPI 2 
 
Hey all! I have a weird situation and I‚Äôm not sure if I need actual advice or just need to talk this out and have someone else confirm what I think I know. 

I have my LLC set and plan to get my cash practice up and running in the next few months. I‚Äôd like my patients to be able to submit super bills. Need to figure out NPI. 

When I started my first job out of school, I was practicing under some type of group NPI through a large health system. I set up an NPI1 about 7 years ago when I moved out of state, changed jobs, and started working for a place that billed as a private practice. I left that job after 1 year and since then have gone back to working with the original large health system PRN. Never updated any info for my NPI. 

Option 1: Set up an NPI2, do not enroll with Medicare. Update address info on NPI1. Do I need to do anything with NPI1, like unenroll with Medicare? What about other insurance companies that I may have been affiliated with during my 1-yr private practice stint? No idea how to find out that info if needed. 

Option 2: Update my NPI1. From what I‚Äôm reading, if you‚Äôre an LLC and you‚Äôre not incorporated, you can use your NPI1. Still not sure what I have to do with Medicare or previously contracted insurance companies. 

Will any of these changes affect my ability to work PRN for the large healthcare system? As I mentioned, I believe I function under a group NPI (maybe their NPI2?) as I didn‚Äôt have my own for the first 3 years of my career. 

Thanks for any insight, shared experiences, or advice!

comments.text: U don't have contracts under your npi if u want medicare u need a new medicare number.  Mostly insurances contract with type 2 group npi.  Ur type 1 npi number should still be good it follows u for life but u have to update on caqh find out ur password and reattest
Your NPI is associated with the other clinics you work for but under they group NPI. Anything you do under your business will not be associated with any insurance contracts.

post_text: As a PT ( mobile out patient ) , can I add weight loss program and have a nutritionist work with me for private client..

comments.text: I‚Äôd make sure you are working with a registered dietitian rather than a nutritionist. Many states only allow RDs to legally provide meal plans, and all states only allow RDs to do medical nutrition therapy of medical conditions, which obesity can fall under. RDs are licensed professionals with a formal education and licensure just like us. Nutritionist is an unregulated term in many states, so literally anyone with either no education or with a 2 hour online certification can claim to be a nutritionist. Working with an RD would keep you safely within the law and offer much higher quality!
does your state practice act and liability insurance allow it ???

full_thread_text:

RDs are licensed professionals with a formal education and licensure just like us. Nutritionist is an unregulated term in many states, so literally anyone with either no education or with a 2 hour online certification can claim to be a nutritionist. Working with an RD would keep you safely within the law and offer much higher quality!

post_text:
For anyone with a business that your started before 2024, there are two legal things you need to do by the end of the year:
1. Authenticate Your Domain through your email provider (to comply with a new law and not have your emails go to spam)
1. File for BOI (to confirm you are the owner) - https://boiefiling.fincen.gov/

Note: I apologize, but I do not have time to go into details about these things. These are based on two laws that came out this year for business owners. I am not an expert, but was guided by one of my mentors/friends who owns a business that this is something to do. I shared this to be helpful and I am absolutely not an expert on this nor am I aiming to be. Feel free to look up more details on your own if you are unsure.

post_text:
Rookie here.

I'm looking to become an independent PT in Illinois, and after doing my research, I need to start a PLLC instead of just an LLC. Could some of you point me in the right direction on how to get the PLLC process started? I've been digging, but the more I do, the more confused I become...Plus, what are your thoughts on being your own Registered Agent versus hiring a third-party company to be your RA? Any links and/or comments with further information is incredibly appreciated. Thanks in advance!

comments.text:
You can‚Äôt do the paperwork online for a pllc in Illinois‚Ä¶ as hard as I tried üòÇ you have to mail it in, with a certified check or cash. Took about 4 weeks I believe to process. I elected to use a friend who‚Äôs a lawyer as my
Registered agent. But I know others locally who used themselves or their accountant. It will make them the point of contact for renewals and probably other things that I forget now.

I‚Äôm in NY so I‚Äôm not sure if this is how it works in Illinois but in order to form a PLLC you have to have your state physical therapy license first verified (in NY you go through the dept of Ed and get a certificate approving it) then you file the articles of incorporation with Secretary of State. I do believe you are more protected with a PLLC over an LLC so I think it‚Äôs worth it IMO.

post_text: Hey everyone, I have a question about a lawyer requesting notes. We have been treating a patient for a few months now and the patient was in a car accident in December. Our treatment diagnosis is unrelated to his car accident. His lawyer wants us to send him our notes, which are completely unrelated to the car accident. However, the lawyer is telling the patient to request the notes and gave the patient an email for us to send them to rather than sending us a formal request. I told the patient to tell the lawyer that he needs to send a formal request and then we will send the notes. Does anyone know the legality behind this? I should not just send these notes to the lawyers email without a request, correct?

comments.text: The records technically belong to the patient.  If you make the patient sign a medical records release form (just to protect you), you can give them to the patient and they can give them willingly to whomever they please.
Tell the lawyer , via the email your patient gave you, to send you a medical records release signed by the patient /client releasing the records to their lawyer .

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone, I have a question about a lawyer requesting notes. We have been treating a patient for a few months now and the patient was in a car accident in December. Our treatment diagnosis is unrelated to his car accident. His lawyer wants us to send him our notes, which are completely unrelated to the car accident. However, the lawyer is telling the patient to request the notes and gave the patient an email for us to send them to rather than sending us a formal request. I told the patient to tell the lawyer that he needs to send a formal request and then we will send the notes. Does anyone know the legality behind this? I should not just send these notes to the lawyers email without a request, correct?

COMMENT 1: The records technically belong to the patient.  If you make the patient sign a medical records release form (just to protect you), you can give them to the patient and they can give them willingly to whomever they please.

COMMENT 2: Tell the lawyer , via the email your patient gave you, to send you a medical records release signed by the patient /client releasing the records to their lawyer .

post_text:
I called myPTinsurance to inquire about liability coverage. 

They have 2 options: 

$297/yr for self-employed and 
$149/yr for employed. 

It only covers the clinician and not the practice/LLC. 

There is literally no difference in the policy coverage in those 2 options as per the person who spoke with me. 

I asked in different ways of why someone would pay more if there is no difference in the coverage. She was very casual about pick whichever you want. ü§Ø 

Does anyone know if there is any difference in self-employed policy vs employed? 

I further asked if there was ever a claim then do you provider legal guidance and she said we don‚Äôt provider any legal guidance. You just submit your claim to the claims department. 

I am wondering if she was a new employee on the call who has no idea how to answer the call when a new client calls. 

Looking for any helpful information I can get from this group. 

Thank you in advance.

comments.text: If you are self-employed this would be your only coverage, so in the event of an incident, this company would be the sole coverage, so they charge more to cover that potential cost. If you are employed, you are likely covered by your employer‚Äôs liability insurance also, and if the incident occurred during the time you are working for them, that would cover the majority of the cost. This coverage would be secondary

I second CM&F. 

If you are working for someone else, they should have a liability umbrella policy for the business. In that case you would purchase supplemental insurance as an employed person.

If you are running your own business then you need coverage for yourself and the business. That would be professional and general liability. That is self-employed insurance.

For a company covering me if I do soldering wrong or accidentally cause damage or an injury, I want them knowing what they‚Äôre doing and what they‚Äôre talking about. myPTinsurance always looked to good to be true. They also never had enough information to make it look legit.

I am wondering if she was a new employee on the call who has no idea how to answer the call when a new client calls. 

Looking for any helpful information I can get from this group. 

Thank you in advance.

COMMENT 1: If you are self-employed this would be your only coverage, so in the event of an incident, this company would be the sole coverage, so they charge more to cover that potential cost. If you are employed, you are likely covered by your employer‚Äôs liability insurance also, and if the incident occurred during the time you are working for them, that would cover the majority of the cost. This coverage would be secondary

COMMENT 2: I second CM&F. 

If you are working for someone else, they should have a liability umbrella policy for the business. In that case you would purchase supplemental insurance as an employed person.

If you are running your own business then you need coverage for yourself and the business. That would be professional and general liability. That is self-employed insurance.

For a company covering me if I do soldering wrong or accidentally cause damage or an injury, I want them knowing what they‚Äôre doing and what they‚Äôre talking about. myPTinsurance always looked to good to be true. They also never had enough information to make it look legit.

I have HPSO liability insurance, they came back stating that I need to insure myself as a PT AND my business separately. I am the only employee under my LLC (part-time <24 hrs). They were quoting close to $1000. Does this sound right? TY
Lesli JenkinsJosh PayneDavid BayliffKevin DeGroot

comments.text: The safer bet would be to insure yourself individually and insure the company itself especially if you have employees. The whole point is for individuals not to sue you personally or go after your personal assets. You can definitely ask several people about this including your insurance agent, your CPA, or your small business attorney. You will have to calculate the risk on your part to determine the benefit of insuring both and how much patient care you're actually doing.
From HPSO, yep, that‚Äôs pretty accurate.

You technically can as a sole proprietor without establishing an LLC or other business (depends on your state). Definitely need liability insurance for yourself.

Most will advise to establish your company though for liability protection against your personal assets in case something happens. You don‚Äôt want to risk personal things in the rare event something happens.

COMMENT 2: You technically can as a sole proprietor without establishing an LLC or other business (depends on your state). Definitely need liability insurance for yourself.

Most will advise to establish your company though for liability protection against your personal assets in case something happens. You don‚Äôt want to risk personal things in the rare event something happens.

post_text: Hi! Starting a mobile PT LLC and had a few questions regarding applying for a group NPI. I plan to be contracted with Medicare. 1) Do I need a business NPI or can I use my individual NPI/are the pros/cons to applying for a group NPI? 2) when I went to apply for the NPI type 2(organization NPI) it was required to put down a practice location (physical address not a PO Box)‚Ä¶ but what do you do if you are mobile and don‚Äôt have a location? Thanks in advance!

comments.text: Hi, you will need a type 2 NPI to bill Medicare with your own business. When it comes to practice location you can either put your home address or set up a virtual location (I'm not too sure on how to do this as I just did my home address but it is an option). On the bright side having the type 2 NPI will allow you to get paid through your LLC which opens up all the possible tax advantages of owning a business vs being a W2 employee

post_text:
Hi friends! Need guidance, I am physical therapist in Indiana, and reside in Louisville. My question is if I rent a house in Indiana and at the same time continuing staying in Louisville, will that be legal to apply for PT compact license for Kentucky state? I talked to Kentucky board for the PT compact license, they replied u need to have Indiana ID to apply for that. And then I am thinking this way renting a house and getting Indiana DL and then PT compact license for KY. Will that work? Or is there anything wrong doing this way? Please guide.
TIA

comments.text: I‚Äôve lived in KY (Lou) and worked in IN (Clarksville). I only had my Indiana license for most of that time, but later did have licenses in both KY and IN (compact wasn‚Äôt yet an option). I now live in Indiana and have compact privileges in KY. Super easy process both ways honestly. To have compact privileges, you have to hold a full license in your home state of residence - so for example, I couldn‚Äôt have lived in KY, had my regular license in IN, and then applied for KY compact privileges. Because I live in IN and hold my regular license in IN, I‚Äôm free to apply for compact privileges in any participating state. Does that make sense? I think I‚Äôm confused as to why you would rent a house in Indiana if you‚Äôre staying in Lou?
Again evaluation from fccpt and then credits TOEFL jurisprudence

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôve lived in KY (Lou) and worked in IN (Clarksville). I only had my Indiana license for most of that time, but later did have licenses in both KY and IN (compact wasn‚Äôt yet an option). I now live in Indiana and have compact privileges in KY. post_text:
Hi all, I'm registering for a PLLC. Do I have to have the words "Physical Therapy" in the company name, or can it be just "PT?"

I'm in New York.

On the ny.gov website, it states the following: 

A certificate pursuant to Business Corporation Law, section 1503 (b) (ii) may be issued when:
1. the proposed name of the corporation appropriately describes the profession practiced and the services to be provided; and

Your application will be rejected if you do not submit an explanation for words used in your entity name that are: initials, foreign words, surnames, abbreviations or words not commonly used in connection with the profession(s) being practiced ([Business Corporation Law, Article 15](https://public.leginfo.state.ny.us/LAWSSEAF.cgi?QUERYTYPE=LAWS+&QUERYDATA=%24%24BSC1503%24%24%40TXBSC01503+&LIST=LAW+&BROWSER=EXPLORER+&TOKEN=27738319+&TARGET=VIEW); [Regulations of the Commissioner of Education, Part 59, Section 59.10](https://www.op.nysed.gov/title8/regulations-commissioner-education/part-59#psc); [Board of Regents Rule 29.1](https://www.op.nysed.gov/title8/rules-board-regents/part-29)).

... but I don't see a space to explain what the initials PT mean.

And  I also found this on the nysed.gov website:

Guideline 2: Advertising and Specialty Credentials

The initials used in connection with a licensed physical therapist's or physical therapist assistant‚Äôs name are "P.T." or "P.T.A." Although an individual can include the academic degree in one‚Äôs signature, these designations are neither recognized nor protected by Education Law or the Rules of the Regents. The title should be listed first after the person‚Äôs name, i.e., Jane Smith, PT, MSPT, DPT, OCS.

comments.text: In New York, YES.  Your name must include ‚ÄúPhysical Therapy‚Äù

post_text:
Non-PT specific HIPAA question:

** UPDATE:  Both providers easily relented after I sent an explanation article about the Cures Act and explained that I can also just get the results myself from the lab / that it is now routine to get immediate results from traditional healthcare via patient portals.  Education for the win! I also have prior personal relationships with both people so it wasn‚Äôt a hard fight. **

Through HIPAA, it is my right to have access to my medical records including lab reports, etc upon request.  For example, when I get testing via my PCP, I get the results immediately when they are available.  Labcorp notifies me and I can access independent of talking to the order physician.  

I've had 2 functional medicine providers refuse to share test results with me until I meet with them.  One is a chiropractor and the other is nutritionist.  

As a cash-PT myself, I've heard that HIPPA doesn't necessarily apply if i'm not involved with insurance.  Yet, I follow HIPPA as that is the standard and what patients expect.  Also because i'm not certain when and when it doesn't apply so it's safer to just follow the rules.

SO...  Should I expect the same access to my medical records and test results from the Functional medicine providers?  Or does HIPAA not apply to them since insurance is not involved?

comments.text: I personally would expect to be able to see the results. You are paying for them in some form, even if included in the ‚Äúeval‚Äù price.  That sounds a little concerning.
Yeah chiros and functional med are notorious for this. I've contacted the lab on my own before and even requested them through my clinic or a friend's to circumvent. It's ridiculous.

post_text: If I have a mobile private practice (doing OT in client‚Äôs home), is liability insurance through HPSO (coverage 1 mil/claim, 3mil/aggregate) $120/yr sufficient or do I need more coverage?

comments.text: I also made sure my policy included general and professional liability. General covers other things like someone falling in your parking lot (which I realize is different with a mobile practice but it‚Äôs that kind of thing vs something happening as a result of their treatment).

I worked for a big company and was named in a lawsuit from a former patient along with all other providers involved in her care. 
What I learned was that they go after the biggest insurance policy. Since I was covered by the company policy and didn‚Äôt have a separate one for myself, they removed my name and didn‚Äôt come after personal assets. So my takeaway is carry a reasonable amount like the $1m/$3m and if you have more then they‚Äôll just go after more in a lawsuit.

full_thread_text:
POST: If I have a mobile private practice (doing OT in client‚Äôs home), is liability insurance through HPSO (coverage 1 mil/claim, 3mil/aggregate) $120/yr sufficient or do I need more coverage?

COMMENT 1: I also made sure my policy included general and professional liability. General covers other things like someone falling in your parking lot (which I realize is different with a mobile practice but it‚Äôs that kind of thing vs something happening as a result of their treatment).

COMMENT 2: I worked for a big company and was named in a lawsuit from a former patient along with all other providers involved in her care. 
What I learned was that they go after the biggest insurance policy. Since I was covered by the company policy and didn‚Äôt have a separate one for myself, they removed my name and didn‚Äôt come after personal assets. So my takeaway is carry a reasonable amount like the $1m/$3m and if you have more then they‚Äôll just go after more in a lawsuit.

post_text:
When getting liability insurance to start my own LLC, how much coverage is needed? (OT private home based practice)

Per incident limit: 500,000 vs 1,000,000
Aggregate limit 1 vs 3 vs 6,000,000

And do I need the general liability added? 

Thanks in advance

comments.text: Go for the bigger one.

What matters most is YOUR comfort level of coverage.  You SHOULD have coverage. As an OT (or PT), the likelihood of you "getting into trouble" is very very slim. Still, get coverage.  Could you go with $500K and $1M and no general? Sure.  Does that make YOU comfortable with your coverage? Only you know the answer

post_text: Do we have to provide clients with a form with info about HIPPA? And consent for services? A credit card authorization form? Consent form for telepractice? Trying to figure out if it‚Äôs worth purchasing a package of forms offered to private practice SLPs for $347.

comments.text:
#Compliance - expert advice - the forms are of no use unless there are corresponding polices, procedures & processes in place.  

For example: HIPAA is a federal law - with significant requirements... having a patient "acknowledge" receipt of "your" Notice of Privacy Practices is of no value is you don't have policies governing all the privacy practice, patient instructions on how to access their privacy rights, etc.

post_text:
PLLC set up for NY State questions:
Does the name need to have Physical Therapy in it , if so,  can it be abbreviated to PT or must it be spelled out?
Does the NYS.gov have a master list so I can look up to see if the choices I thought of have been taken?
Do the folks with mobile PT plus wellness plus any other training or non medical issues use 2 separate PLLCs or can it be combined into a name like : "XXX PT health and wellness"
TIA!!

comments.text: I‚Äôm in NY and recently opened up my private OT practice. The LLC had to have OT in it, but you can register a DBA for whatever name you want. However, I believe for tax purposes, you need to keep it through your LLC name. Good luck!

The corp must have the professional license in the name in your case being ‚ÄúPhysical Therapy‚Äù however I believe you can file a DBA after the corp is formed that does not require the name to be in it. Another option would be to trademark a name/logo and brand the practice under that. 

You can go to the NY dept. of state and perform an entity search of the name that you are looking for and it will show all registered NYS businesses.

full_thread_text:
POST: PLLC set up for NY State questions:
Does the name need to have Physical Therapy in it , if so,  can it be abbreviated to PT or must it be spelled out?
Does the NYS.gov have a master list so I can look up to see if the choices I thought of have been taken?
Do the folks with mobile PT plus wellness plus any other training or non medical issues use 2 separate PLLCs or can it be combined into a name like : "XXX PT health and wellness"
TIA!!

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôm in NY and recently opened up my private OT practice. The LLC had to have OT in it, but you can register a DBA for whatever name you want. However, I believe for tax purposes, you need to keep it through your LLC name. Good luck!

COMMENT 2: The corp must have the professional license in the name in your case being ‚ÄúPhysical Therapy‚Äù however I believe you can file a DBA after the corp is formed that does not require the name to be in it. Another option would be to trademark a name/logo and brand the practice under that. 

You can go to the NY dept. of state and perform an entity search of the name that you are looking for and it will show all registered NYS businesses.

post_text: Hi all! I am in the early stages of starting my mobile PT business. I know this topic has been discussed on here before, but after looking through old posts, I am still needing some clarity. Is there anyone in Idaho or Washington state who knows if PLLC is required over LLC? I know it varies state to state. I have searched Secretary of State website, called them directly, and have looked over Idaho business statues, but still I am not seeing it spelled out. Wondering if anyone here knows. If it is not required, is there benefit to going with PLLC rather than LLC? I don‚Äôt plan to have employees, so I don‚Äôt know if the protections a PLLC offers is worth the potential extra time or steps it takes for application?

comments.text: No benefit to PLLC unless multi members- you aren't liable for another members mistakes/malpractice, whereas an LLC you can be. There's no other benefit, PLLC just requires all owners maintain a state licensure. Not sure on your state req.

I am in WA state and hired a lawyer to help me set everything up. She originally set me up as an LLC but realized (after all the paperwork was done) that she made a mistake and I needed to be a PLLC. Luckily, she was a fantastic person and didn't charge me extra for the extra paperwork. All this to say, I hired a lawyer and she said PLLC. What she explained to me was that I have a Professional license and therefore it had to be PLLC.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I am in the early stages of starting my mobile PT business. I know this topic has been discussed on here before, but after looking through old posts, I am still needing some clarity. Is there anyone in Idaho or Washington state who knows if PLLC is required over LLC? I know it varies state to state. I have searched Secretary of State website, called them directly, and have looked over Idaho business statues, but still I am not seeing it spelled out. Wondering if anyone here knows. If it is not required, is there benefit to going with PLLC rather than LLC? I don‚Äôt plan to have employees, so I don‚Äôt know if the protections a PLLC offers is worth the potential extra time or steps it takes for application?

COMMENT 1: No benefit to PLLC unless multi members- you aren't liable for another members mistakes/malpractice, whereas an LLC you can be. There's no other benefit, PLLC just requires all owners maintain a state licensure. Not sure on your state req.

COMMENT 2: I am in WA state and hired a lawyer to help me set everything up. She originally set me up as an LLC but realized (after all the paperwork was done) that she made a mistake and I needed to be a PLLC. Luckily, she was a fantastic person and didn't charge me extra for the extra paperwork. All this to say, I hired a lawyer and she said PLLC. What she explained to me was that I have a Professional license and therefore it had to be PLLC.

post_text:
Hi Everyone! I am so grateful for this community for keeping the vision alive and the passion in my heart. 

I left my outpatient job earlier this year and when initially meeting with an attorney was told my non-compete most likely wasn‚Äôt valid and that if I was providing mobile cash services (that my previous company didn‚Äôt offer) I wouldn‚Äôt have to worry about my non compete at all. I went ahead and started the bootcamp course, established an LLC and the early steps of beginning my business. Then when I met with him again he had oddly flipped his advice and said after further review he felt it was completely valid and I should just lay low for the 18 month non compete term. I feel SO stuck. I have multiple people reaching out for services and I am terrified to move forward. I have a good relationship with my previous employer and told them my intention‚Äôs. It‚Äôs a company with 3 owners, two of which I directly worked with and know well. The third was relatively removed and not the friendliest individual. My direct boss even offered to mentor me and share his business journey. BUT something in my gut is telling me to tread carefully because I don‚Äôt entirely trust they wouldn‚Äôt pursue something if I completely disregarded the non compete. The attorney‚Äôs recommendation was to save any profits I make if they do decide to pursue litigation. I have seen a few people cash pay but now I feel as if I shouldn‚Äôt. I took a job at a local facility for the time being and I even had a previous patient contact me at my new job asking for services. I feel like it‚Äôs such a disservice to my previous clients to just ‚Äúlay low‚Äù for 18 months but I really don‚Äôt want to end up in litigation. 

What are other peoples experiences with these types of situations? If I do wait the full 18 months what courses, resources, or readings would you recommend I work on in the mean time to be ready to hit the ground running when the time is right? 

Sorry for the rant! I‚Äôm reviewing the boot camp course again today and feel so torn on how to move forward. I miss my patients and I just have so many ideas I can‚Äôt wait to explore. 18 months feels like an eternity but I know it‚Äôs not the end of the world.

comments.text: Mobile. Set your office address outside the milage of the non compete. Simple.
Most non-competes for our type of work won‚Äôt stand up in court. I would continue on

post_text:
Think I got to the bottom of the confusion. 
ÔøºDe facto v. de jure. 
People are confused about 1099 and W-2. The reason is the government has built-in healthcare rules that go against 1099 rules. Ie‚Ä¶ Ôøº you aren‚Äôt supposed to pay for your contractors HIPAA compliant email but you also are not supposed to tell them how to run business. The problem is in order to run the business, they need a HIPAA compliant email. Do you see how the problem is built into the solution üëÄüëÄüëÄ Ôøº how many electricians plumbers and carpenters do you know w a hipaa  compliant email?? üëÄüëÄ working against us. 
It‚Äôs purposeful confusion. (Yes. I spent the past week studying the differences) üî•üî•

post_text:
Question (my apologies if this has been asked). I am a sports PT and have my CSCS. I have recently been approached by two people who want me to train them privately. I do not hold a personal training cert specifically. I have heard in a lawsuit they can go after your highest license so I definitely want to protect myself. Is this something I can offer to people under ‚Äúwellness‚Äù making it clear it is not PT? If so, what are some things I should consider setting up ahead of time such as an LLC, liability insurance, consent forms reviewed by a lawyer etc? Want to ensure I‚Äôm strategic about this. 

Thanks!

comments.text: You definitely always want to delineate between skilled PT services and non skilled PT services whether you name it wellness or something else. However, in a court of law, and to your state PT board,  you can't be a PT sometimes and not be a PT other times. We are always PTs and we give advice and guidance based off of our expertise as PTs. This is why you can train someone in a wellness AND a rehab program. Your malpractice insurance covers you, it doesn't delineate whether or not you're doing PT stuff bc your are a always a PT.

Yup! LLC I would just have your name & wellness (not required, just a double safety net) clear consent / client contract forms they sign ‚Äúunderstand this is not PT‚Äù , and get liability insurance to cover that highest degree

post_text:
Little confused on Liability insurance: I just called CMF and she quoted me approximately $450-500 for the year for 1 employee working full time, $200-300  for part time ( I can't remember the exact amount she quoted but it was in that ball park range for the year). The agent also said it covered everything that " a PT could do via their practice act for the State I was practicing in," and that it would cover me and the business at this time and any secretarial or other admins that currently are apart of or will be apart of the company. But I'd have to change to a group plan once I add more clinicians. Okay, that makes sense to me. 

My question is, after reading some posts- what am I missing- as I see some indicating a general plan and a professional insurance? Would I need an additional plan for malpractice insurance? I was ways under the impression CMF was malpractice insurance.

comments.text: This stuff is clear as mud because they don't just call it malpractice insurance, which I wish they would. I have CM&F, and my understanding is that professional liability insurance = malpractice. I treat you and you are personally harmed as a result of the treatment. Business liability = related to the business itself. So if you go into a home and break a lamp while providing your business service, that would be business liability -not personal injury as a result of physical therapy treatment, but a damage that occurred while doing business. Or if you have a brick and mortar and someone tripped on the way in and breaks their arm- again a damage that occurred while doing business, not related to the provision of therapy services specifically. I would get both.

I have a plan with them. I can check my paperwork but I believe it is malpractice and when signing up you can add general liability, which I did. My landlord also requires that piece. But still was half the price of other companies.

Questions for starting a mobile practice (specifically in Tennessee), and apologies if they are common sense questions, business/taxes/billing are NOT my strong suite and I'm working on that: 

1. Is an LLC required? I had an accountant say I would be better operating as a DBA initially. (I don't have any big assets in my name, they are all in my husband's name, not sure if that is relevant). 
1. Do I need a business license? 
1. NPI #- I plan to be cash based only. Can I operate under my personal NPI # from my previous employer or do I need to get a type 2 NPI for business? What about if I want to provide a superbill?
1. For TN, direct access has a 90-day window and states we must refer out if they are not making progress. We also must contact physician after 90 days, does this apply with cash based practice too? What is the goal when contacting the physician if we are not needing to request more visits or provide progress note etc. 

TIA!!

comments.text:
Hi! I'm in Knoxville and just started my mobile practice in October so I have some answers but not many haha.
1. I just went ahead and did the LLC from the start, but you could also just do a sole proprietorship. I don't believe it's required, but not 100% sure on that.
2. I was told we do not need a business license for the state of TN as long as we are not selling goods.
3. I have seen different answers on what type of NPI so I'm not sure. As for now, I only have my personal NPI bc it's just me in the practice. 
4. Some advice in this group is that reaching out to the MD is a sort of marketing tool. I believe it's required even if cash-based, but again I'm not 100% sure. 

Sorry my answers are not great, hope they help a bit!

comments.text:
#HIPAA #Compliance - "True" as noted by Allyson - a patient can elect, under specific circumstances to receipt of unsecure emails. 

A big HOWEVER - under your (mandatory) HIPAA Security Risk Assessment, how have you addressed the Administrative, Physical, & Technical Safeguards under the Security Rule in your P & P?  That is where your risk mitigation lies.

Best of luck. GoToTheSource

post_text: Hey, me again lol. Is it necessary to have an LLC, or can I just operate under my license and malpractice insurance? What is the benefit of having an LLC? I am going to work super minimal hours at first, like <10, only cash, I'm the only PT.

comments.text:
Separation of church and state.   You treat a patient as yourself. They sue you they can come after all of your assets etc.    if you‚Äôre a business. Your personal life is kept away from the business. 
It takes 1 hour and maybe a $200 to set up a basic LLC.

The LLC protects your personal assets. Without the LLC if there is litigation, your assets could be taken as opposed to the businesses assets. 100% would go with an LLC. Also look for state run financial institutes that certify an LLC- don‚Äôt go through legal zoom üòâ

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey, me again lol. Is it necessary to have an LLC, or can I just operate under my license and malpractice insurance? What is the benefit of having an LLC? I am going to work super minimal hours at first, like <10, only cash, I'm the only PT.

COMMENT 1: Separation of church and state.   You treat a patient as yourself. They sue you they can come after all of your assets etc.    if you‚Äôre a business. Your personal life is kept away from the business. 
It takes 1 hour and maybe a $200 to set up a basic LLC.

COMMENT 2: The LLC protects your personal assets. Without the LLC if there is litigation, your assets could be taken as opposed to the businesses assets. 100% would go with an LLC. Also look for state run financial institutes that certify an LLC- don‚Äôt go through legal zoom üòâ

post_text:
Hello everyone! I've officially started my in-home pediatric private practice this month (yay!!) and have been using Zelle for accepting payments. I now have a new patient who is "challenging" me on this and states they do not want to use Zelle because it is not HIPAA compliant. Can anyone help me with this?

I've deep dived the internet and there are random articles stating it is necessary to have HIPAA compliant payment methods and some other articles saying otherwise. I've finally found a more reliable source, but am still questioning myself on the proper/legal way to go about this.

https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/business-associates/index.html
* if you look at the last paragraph of this link, I think it's clear that payment methods are exempt...however, I'm unsure if it's simply stating I don't need the signed BAA portion, but still need to be  "HIPAA compliant"?

In addition, the parents wants me to remove my privacy notice section stating I have permission to access their medical record and speak to their PCP; parents want it to be on a case-by-case basis. I don't mind changing the form for them, but would this cause issues in the future??

THANK YOU, this group has been extremely helpful in helping me start my business and feel more confident in it :)

comments.text: Sounds like a complicated client/parent. Challenging you etc. Tell them to pay you cash or check if they don't want to zelle you. Or get a credit card reader from PayPal or any other provider.

I'd be concerned about them not wanting you to speak with the child's physician. What if there is an issue that needs to be communicated? You would solely be reliant on the parents and you wouldn't know what was actually communicated.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello everyone! I've officially started my in-home pediatric private practice this month (yay!!) and have been using Zelle for accepting payments. I now have a new patient who is "challenging" me on this and states they do not want to use Zelle because it is not HIPAA compliant. Can anyone help me with this?

I've deep dived the internet and there are random articles stating it is necessary to have HIPAA compliant payment methods and some other articles saying otherwise. I've finally found a more reliable source, but am still questioning myself on the proper/legal way to go about this.

https://www.hhs.gov/hipaa/for-professionals/privacy/guidance/business-associates/index.html
* if you look at the last paragraph of this link, I think it's clear that payment methods are exempt...however, I'm unsure if it's simply stating I don't need the signed BAA portion, but still need to be  "HIPAA compliant"?

In addition, the parents wants me to remove my privacy notice section stating I have permission to access their medical record and speak to their PCP; parents want it to be on a case-by-case basis. I don't mind changing the form for them, but would this cause issues in the future??

THANK YOU, this group has been extremely helpful in helping me start my business and feel more confident in it :)

COMMENT 1: Sounds like a complicated client/parent. Challenging you etc. Tell them to pay you cash or check if they don't want to zelle you. Or get a credit card reader from PayPal or any other provider.

COMMENT 2: I'd be concerned about them not wanting you to speak with the child's physician. What if there is an issue that needs to be communicated? You would solely be reliant on the parents and you wouldn't know what was actually communicated.

post_text: Hey all I had a third party auditer reach out and request medical records for an Aetna Medicare client. They have said that it is not a payment audit and are just collecting records for documentation quality. Is this standard practice? Has anyone else had this occur?

comments.text: #Compliance Yes, it is standards practice, and Advantage Plans are required to submit data to CMS in support of their "risk adjustment" scores (how they are paid based on patient severity). If you have a contract  - it will be identified in the contract as cooperating w/quality review, or similar verbiage.
