If you have a contract  - it will be identified in the contract as cooperating w/quality review, or similar verbiage.

post_text:
It's already mid-week everybody! I hope you are all doing pretty well. I am planning to put up a LLC with the goal of converting it to a cash-based business in the future but for now, I am trying to contract with a home health agency. 

What are the main licenses I should apply for given my current goal? State, local and federal licenses? Do I need health permits/medical licenses before I can start using my business?

Thank you all for sharing your thoughts. I have more in the way as I also read through some online articles.

comments.text: Your business will need to be set up with your secretary of state. Some states (including your state practice board) may have requirements about whether it is an LLC or PLLC. You need to check with that. Then you need to apply for an EIN with the IRS for your business. Now your business is ready to contract with the home health agency. I would also recommend applying for a type 2 NPI for your business as well. Feel free to reach out if you have any other questions.

full_thread_text:

Thank you all for sharing your thoughts. I have more in the way as I also read through some online articles.

COMMENT 1: Your business will need to be set up with your secretary of state. Some states (including your state practice board) may have requirements about whether it is an LLC or PLLC. You need to check with that. Then you need to apply for an EIN with the IRS for your business. Now your business is ready to contract with the home health agency. I would also recommend applying for a type 2 NPI for your business as well. Feel free to reach out if you have any other questions.

post_text: Anyone have experience with setting up and developing a business as a Medicare Part B physical therapist provider? I got my NPI, but it seems that you need to register as a business provider in order to see Medicare B patients. Please correct me if I‚Äôm wrong‚Ä¶

comments.text: So I help people regularly with this. You will need several things in place. Firstly you will need to have your state business license, then get an EIN. If it is not an LLC/PLLC (depends on your state) then you enroll as a sole prop. If an LLC/PLLC you will then apply for a Type 2 NPI. You then need to open a business bank account and have a bank letter or voided check. Make sure all the names match even to the commas. Once you have all that in place then you can start your application for credentialing with Medicare and to reassign your personal NPI to your business.

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone have experience with setting up and developing a business as a Medicare Part B physical therapist provider? I got my NPI, but it seems that you need to register as a business provider in order to see Medicare B patients. Please correct me if I‚Äôm wrong‚Ä¶

COMMENT 1: So I help people regularly with this. You will need several things in place. Firstly you will need to have your state business license, then get an EIN. If it is not an LLC/PLLC (depends on your state) then you enroll as a sole prop. If an LLC/PLLC you will then apply for a Type 2 NPI. You then need to open a business bank account and have a bank letter or voided check. Make sure all the names match even to the commas. Once you have all that in place then you can start your application for credentialing with Medicare and to reassign your personal NPI to your business.

post_text:
Liability insurance question

I‚Äôm researching liability insurance and trying to get an idea of where to get it and what kind to get. I know I need malpractice/professional liability, but I‚Äôm trying to determine if I need general or not. I am starting as a mobile business with no physical location. Every time I select general coverage they want to know how many physical locations there are. I don‚Äôt have one. I will only use my home for paperwork and accounting. Do I need general? I feel like based on the description of it, I do need it. But based on the physical location requirement, I don‚Äôt. Help?

comments.text: I use Lockton  and they provided a general liability policy as part of the offering for my professional liability policy. So I got both for 1 price. That was when I was 100% mobile. Now I have an office and purchased a different general policy. If you break something or run your car into your patients property, you need general liability to cover that.

I have general and professional but I have therapists working for me. General covers everything that doesn‚Äôt fall under malpractice. Most mobile clinics do have a physical location‚Ä¶ your home. If you happen to see a patient at your house you will probably need general. It would also cover cyber breaches I believe.

full_thread_text:
POST: Liability insurance question

I‚Äôm researching liability insurance and trying to get an idea of where to get it and what kind to get. I know I need malpractice/professional liability, but I‚Äôm trying to determine if I need general or not. I am starting as a mobile business with no physical location. Every time I select general coverage they want to know how many physical locations there are. I don‚Äôt have one. I will only use my home for paperwork and accounting. Do I need general? I feel like based on the description of it, I do need it. But based on the physical location requirement, I don‚Äôt. Help?

COMMENT 1: I use Lockton  and they provided a general liability policy as part of the offering for my professional liability policy. So I got both for 1 price. That was when I was 100% mobile. Now I have an office and purchased a different general policy. If you break something or run your car into your patients property, you need general liability to cover that.

COMMENT 2: I have general and professional but I have therapists working for me. General covers everything that doesn‚Äôt fall under malpractice. Most mobile clinics do have a physical location‚Ä¶ your home. If you happen to see a patient at your house you will probably need general. It would also cover cyber breaches I believe.

post_text: Does anyone know if a bathroom in a brick and mortar PT office needs to be ADA compliant in order to see Medicare patients? I do really want my space to be ADA compliant but I just got renovation estimates and they are pretty costly. I do know a portion of that is tax deductible. This will be a small PT clinic with 3-4 employees maximum. TIA!

comments.text:
ADA requires that health care entities provides full and equal access for people with disabilities. Private practice falls under Title III of the ADA.

All it takes is one disgruntled person filing a complaint.

I believe you can ask for time to complete the projects.
Do you know if there is a resource that is specific about what is needed for it to be ADA compliant

POST: Any insight on getting re-licensed as a PT if you let it expire? I assume it might depend a bit on state, I‚Äôm in CO. Is it better to just keep up licensure and all that entails (i.e. continuing education) when you‚Äôre not working if you plan to re-enter years later? I‚Äôm just thinking about years down the road and want to have a plan‚Ä¶

COMMENT 1: Always keep your license. Retesting will be a nightmare and the cost to maintain is minimal.

The test and the prep courses are worth at least 5-10 years of maintaining your license and not using it.

COMMENT 2: I would definitely keep your license up.  Minimal effort and cost to do so and can you even imagine sitting through boards again if you change your mind down the road. üò¨

post_text: Hi! I use Mercer/Proliability for one of my OT small businesses, but I am in the process of setting up a second business with a PT partner. This second business will be only for online educational content (online courses) marketed to the general public (not to other practitioners, or at least not yet). I am really having some struggles with Mercer on getting set up with liability insurance and have been told SO many different things depending on what day I call. Does anyone have a business that has more than 1 business owner, and primarily or only does online courses (not direct therapy services)? It seems weird to pay the same amount that I do for a service-based business when this other business really only needs the educational or non-direct care rider, if that makes sense. Surely someone else out there does this!!! TIA!!
